Having watched/followed quite a few Gundam series (Gundam Wing, Gundam 00, Gundam Unicorn, Gundam AGE and Gundam Build Fighters), my observations are:

- As part of the Real Robot genre, the vast majority of mobile suits are depicted as mass-produced military hardware with limitations similar to that of real-life armored vehicles and aircraft, and so they would be manufactured as complete units ready to fight with no mid-air assembly required.

- A small proportion of mobile suits (e.g. prototypes, the protagonists', enemy aces) come with ejectable cockpits that act as escape pods, although it was suggested that combat data retrieval was prioritized over pilot recovery.

- An even smaller proportion of mobile suits, such as the one depicted in Gundam SEED, do come with mid-air assembly - the in-universe reason is that battle-damaged limbs can be immediately replaced in-field, but quite frankly I suspect that it is the result of Executive Meddling trying to jump on the Super Robot genre bandwagon*.

*Trivia - in the original Mobile Suit Gundam, the RX-78-2 was supposed to have a "realistic" white and grey color scheme. TV execs, however, wanted to sell more toys and merchandise, so they insisted on the garish white/red/blue/yellow scheme we know today.

tl;dr - The only reason for mid-air assembly is because some TV execs thought it looked cool.
